thread.title: Turnbull government ties welfare cuts to NDIS funding
thread.title_full: Turnbull government ties welfare cuts to NDIS funding

author: Adam Gartrell
title: Turnbull government ties welfare cuts to NDIS funding
text:
Pin to Pinterest PIN Link Treasurer Scott Morrison with minister Christian Porter and minister Senator Simon Brimingham at Parliament House in Canberra on Monday 13 February 2017. Photo: Andrew Meares Photo: Andrew Meares 
The Coalition needs nine extra votes to pass the bill, which is scheduled for debate in the lower house later this week. 
The $21 billion NDIS - billed as the biggest social policy program since the introduction of Medicare - was legislated by Labor but its rollout has been largely managed by the Abbott and Turnbull governments. Advertisement 
"This government inherited a black hole when it came to the funding of the NDIS," Mr Morrison said. 
"We inherited an empty promise from the previous government when it came to the NDIS. It wasn't fully funded. We have been working from day one to ensure that we fill that vacuum that was created by the previous government." 
The government has already set aside about $900 million for the NDIS special account. It will build to an estimated $5 billion by 2020, when the scheme is expected to reach up to 500,000 people nationwide. 
By then, the full spending on the scheme will be about $21 billion, with about $11 billion of that to come from the Commonwealth. Other funding will come from existing money in the disability sector and the increase in the Medicare levy. 
Social Services Minister Christian Porter said the government was determined not to fund the scheme by borrowing more or hiking taxes further. 
Labor, which opposes the government's cuts, quickly accused the government of holding the NDIS hostage. 
"This is a disgraceful political game of brinksmanship," said Labor's social services spokeswoman, Jenny Macklin. 
"The NDIS is a bipartisan reform that should be above politics. Instead Mr Turnbull wants to use the NDIS as a bargaining chip in negotiations with the Senate." 
Greens senator Rachel Siewert said it was "robbing Peter to pay Paul" and Australians were sick of such "dirty politics". 
Mr Morrison said the decision would have no impact on the government's budget bottom line because the cost of the NDIS was already factored in.
